text: He sent a man before them, even Joseph, who was sold for a servant:
text_kjv: He sent a man before them, even Joseph, who was sold for a servant:
text_niv: and he sent a man before them—Joseph, sold as a slave.
text_esv: he had sent a man ahead of them, Joseph, who was sold as a slave.
text_nlt: Then he sent someone to Egypt ahead of them —Joseph, who was sold as a slave.
text_msg: But he sent a man on ahead:Joseph, sold as a slave.
text_nasb: He sent a man before them, Joseph, [who] was sold as a slave.
context: Psalm 105 recounts Israel's history, emphasizing God's faithfulness in fulfilling His covenant promises to Abraham and his descendants. Verse 17 focuses specifically on Joseph's story as a pivotal point in that history, illustrating God's providential care. The context is the transition from the patriarchal period to the Israelite sojourn in Egypt. Joseph's brothers, driven by jealousy, sold him into slavery in Egypt. This act of betrayal, intended for evil, was orchestrated by God to preserve Jacob's family during a severe famine. Understanding ancient slavery is crucial. Enslavement wasn't always a permanent condition; it could involve indentured servitude where individuals worked off debts or were prisoners of war. Joseph initially faced harsh conditions, falsely accused and imprisoned. However, his ability to interpret dreams brought him to Pharaoh's attention, leading to his rise to power. This elevation was not mere luck but divine intervention, showcasing God's hand in even the most desperate circumstances. Famines were a recurring threat in the ancient Near East, and societies developed complex systems of grain storage and distribution. Joseph's wisdom in preparing for the famine not only saved Egypt but also drew his family to Egypt, fulfilling God's earlier promise to make Abraham's descendants a great nation. Egypt, at this time, was a major power, and its influence extended throughout the region. The psalm highlights that even amidst hardship and betrayal, God was actively working behind the scenes to secure the future of His chosen people.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 105:17 demonstrates the concept of God's sovereignty and providence. It illustrates that God is in control, even when human actions seem to contradict His purposes. Joseph's enslavement, a seemingly random and cruel event, was part of God's larger plan to preserve His people. This verse challenges the notion that God is passive or uninvolved in human affairs. Instead, it affirms that God actively directs history to achieve His will. The concept of "preparative grace" can be applied here. God often prepares individuals or circumstances in advance to fulfill a future purpose. Joseph's suffering and subsequent rise to power were a preparation for the famine that would necessitate his family's move to Egypt. The verse also alludes to the theme of redemption. What was intended for evil—Joseph's betrayal and enslavement—God transformed into good. This foreshadows the ultimate redemptive act of Jesus Christ, whose suffering and death, though unjust, resulted in salvation for humanity. The verse underscores the importance of trusting God's plan, even when it is unclear or painful. Joseph could not have understood God's purpose in his suffering, but he remained faithful, and God ultimately vindicated him. This speaks to the overarching narrative of the Bible, where God uses brokenness and suffering to bring about His glory and the salvation of His people. It highlights the transformative power of God's grace and His ability to work all things together for good for those who love Him.
application: In modern life, Psalm 105:17 provides several practical applications for believers facing adversity. First, it encourages us to trust in God's sovereignty, even when we don't understand His plan. When facing job loss, relationship difficulties, or health challenges, we can remember Joseph's story and recognize that God is still in control. Secondly, it challenges us to consider how God might be using our present circumstances to prepare us for a future purpose. Are we developing skills, resilience, or empathy that might be used to serve others later on? Thirdly, it reminds us that God can redeem even the most painful experiences. We can find healing and growth through forgiveness, reconciliation, and sharing our stories with others. Consider how Joseph forgave his brothers. This demonstrates a powerful example of responding to injustice with grace. This verse encourages us to view setbacks as opportunities for growth and learning. We can learn from our mistakes, develop new skills, and cultivate a deeper reliance on God. When facing betrayal or injustice, we can choose to respond with compassion and forgiveness, trusting that God will ultimately bring justice and healing. Furthermore, Psalm 105:17 calls us to be proactive in preparing for future challenges. Just as Joseph wisely managed the grain supply in Egypt, we should strive to be responsible stewards of our resources and talents. We can plan for the future, save for emergencies, and invest in our personal and professional development. Finally, we can look for opportunities to serve others in our communities. Joseph's service to Egypt ultimately benefited his family. Similarly, we can use our gifts and talents to make a positive impact on the world around us, trusting that God will use our efforts to bless others.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the story of Joseph and for the reminder that you are sovereign over all things. Help us to trust in your plan, even when we don't understand it. Give us the strength to persevere through difficult times and to see your hand at work in our lives. Teach us to forgive those who have wronged us and to respond to injustice with grace and compassion. Help us to be responsible stewards of our resources and talents, and to use them to serve others. We ask for your guidance and wisdom as we navigate the challenges of life, trusting that you will ultimately bring good out of every situation. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Joseph is mentioned because his story exemplifies God's providence and his role as a precursor to Israel's deliverance. His enslavement and rise to power in Egypt set the stage for the Israelites' eventual migration and preservation during famine, showcasing God's faithfulness.
faqs.question: Q1: Why is Joseph specifically mentioned in Psalm 105:17?

faqs.answer: Joseph's story foreshadows Jesus' life in several ways. Both were betrayed by those closest to them, suffered unjustly, and were ultimately exalted to positions of great power and authority, providing salvation for others through their suffering.
faqs.question: Q2: How does Joseph's story relate to the story of Jesus?

faqs.answer: The verse teaches us that suffering is not necessarily a sign of God's displeasure but can be part of His plan to bring about good. God can use difficult circumstances to prepare us for a future purpose and to ultimately redeem the situation.
faqs.question: Q3: What does Psalm 105:17 teach us about suffering?

faqs.answer: We can apply Joseph's forgiveness by choosing to release bitterness and resentment towards those who have wronged us. This involves acknowledging the hurt, seeking healing through prayer and counseling, and choosing to extend grace to others.
